brand_official_facts.founded_context: Founded in Tokyo, Japan as Tokyo Tsushin Kogyo K.K. (Tokyo Telecommunications Engineering Corporation) by Masaru Ibuka and Akio Morita in the post war period; later adopted the name Sony in 1958.
brand_official_facts.official_purpose: Fill the world with emotion, through the power of creativity and technology.

visual_behavior_summary.one_sentence_behavior: Concept led, idea first advertising that turns technology into a human feeling using bold visual metaphors, clean layouts, and high craft photography.

dominant_axes.futuristic_vs_nostalgic: Hybrid (future facing tech with nostalgic pop culture codes)

creative_strategy_rules.primary_job_to_be_done: Translate complex technology into an instantly graspable human benefit and feeling.
preferred_story_mechanics: visual metaphor that embodies a feature
everyday scenario elevated by product capability
culture and music adjacency without explicit endorsements
avoid: overly literal demonstrations unless used as a single hero scene
visual clutter that competes with the Sony wordmark

signature_looks: high craft studio portraiture with controlled gradients
cinematic outdoor scenes with stylized color casts
macro close ups with tactile realism (skin, eyes, surfaces)
surreal but photoreal installations (large scale props, impossible moments, in camera feel)

preferred: soft directional key light with smooth falloff
clean rim separation on product edges
subtle specular highlights on tech materials
controlled contrast with deep blacks available when concept requires
night_or_moody: cool tonal base with selective warm accents

accent_logic: one strong accent color per execution (often green, cyan, magenta, or electric blue)
accent is used to signal technology or brand energy, not decoration
color_behavior.contrast_behavior: Moderate to high, with large flat color fields or dark negative space to support the concept and logo.

texture_and_material_focus: skin and fabric realism when talent is present
clean transitions and gradients in backgrounds
no visible compression artifacts or banding in hero gradients

composition_principles: single dominant hero image that carries the idea
use of negative space as a premium signal
headline and product callouts kept secondary to the visual idea
clear hierarchy: Sony wordmark, then concept line, then product and legal

logo_rules.clear_space_behavior: Generous clear space, never crowded by copy or product.
interaction_with_imagery: logo often sits in negative space or soft gradient
logo can overlap talent only when contrast and readability are perfect

headline_style: often sentence case or all caps depending on era
sometimes uses dot separated constructions for taglines
typography_behavior.copy_density: Ranges from minimal (one line) to information heavy (legacy print) but always structured in clean blocks.
graphic_motifs: occasional modular color tabs for feature lists

product_packshot_behavior.when_used: Often as a small inset or secondary element for clarity, especially in print.

casting_archetypes: stylized anonymous subjects used as canvases for concept
pose_language: intimacy via close cropping (eyes, profile, hands)
facial_expression_range: sensory engagement rather than overt smiling
wardrobe_behavior: monochrome or muted apparel that does not compete with product
occasional provocative fashion codes used as metaphor, not as sexuality first

verbal_tone: technology fluent but not technical jargon heavy
copy_patterns: imperatives and challenges (how far can you go)
short conceptual tags that frame the visual metaphor
avoid: slang that dates quickly unless intentionally youth coded

recurring_visual_devices: close crop on a single human feature (eye, profile) to represent perception and immersion
product as an extension of the body (headphones integrated, handheld as tactile object)
graphic background fields (solid color or smooth gradient) supporting a single object
surreal object substitution (earphones as a hand gesture, afro as a product halo)
era_blending: legacy print layouts with dense copy coexist with modern minimal executions
consistent emphasis on concept clarity across eras
brand_presence: sub brands appear when relevant (VAIO, PlayStation, Sony Ericsson) but Sony remains the anchor

campaigns_min_10.why_recognizable: Unified global brand message connecting Sony products and entertainment under creativity and technology.

campaigns_min_10.campaign_name: Sony BRAVIA: Colour like no other (Balls)
campaigns_min_10.why_recognizable: Iconic high craft visual spectacle used to communicate color performance.
Explosive color metaphor extending the Bravia color narrative.
Stop motion color world reinforcing vividness and imagination.
Surreal character led film that made the brand feel culturally bold.
Emotional identity driven campaign about the inner life of players.

campaigns_min_10.campaign_name: PlayStation 2: (sleepless nights) and early PS2 print era
campaigns_min_10.why_recognizable: Intimate, uncanny close ups and minimal typographic systems.
Provocative metaphor communicating dual touch surfaces.

campaigns_min_10.campaign_name: Sony Ericsson Walkman: youth music identity posters
campaigns_min_10.why_recognizable: Simple bold color fields with music coded visual metaphors.
Problem solution narrative with a single exaggerated prop and clear copy hierarchy.

must_keep: Sony wordmark placed with generous clear space
high craft lighting and clean gradients
one accent color logic when using bold backgrounds
product fidelity: no distortion of product shape, labels, or key design cues
can_vary: degree of surrealism (from subtle metaphor to full installation)
environment (studio, urban, nature) if it supports human experience
cropping (macro detail to wide scene) provided hierarchy stays clear
copy length (minimal tagline to structured print block) depending on channel
hard_bans: noisy patterned backgrounds unless the pattern is the concept itself
logo placed over complex texture without contrast control
cheap looking CGI or plastic skin rendering
